articles.headline: Clouds Lifting Over Murdoch, He’s Out to Buy Again
articles.snippet: News Corporation delayed deals for more than a year as it dealt with a phone hacking scandal at one of its British publications.
articles.abstract: News Corporation delayed deals for more than a year as it dealt with a phone hacking scandal at one of its British publications.
articles.lead_paragraph: News Corporation is starting to look like its old self again.

articles.headline: Gaza Crisis Poses Threat to Faction Favored by U.S.
articles.snippet: Demonstrations in the West Bank show growing support for Hamas and contempt for the governing Palestinian Authority, which Washington considers the only partner for peace with Israel.
articles.abstract: Demonstrations in the West Bank show growing support for Hamas and contempt for the governing Palestinian Authority, which Washington considers the only partner for peace with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — In the daily demonstrations here of solidarity with Gaza, a mix of sympathy and anguish, there is something else: growing identification with the Islamist fighters of Hamas and derision for the Palestinian Authority, which Washington considers the only viable partner for peace with Israel.

articles.headline: Solar Companies Seek Ways to Build an Oasis of Electricity
articles.snippet: While most solar panel systems are tied to the electrical grid and susceptible to widespread power failures,  there are ways to tap solar energy when the grid goes down.
articles.abstract: While most solar panel systems are tied to the electrical grid and susceptible to widespread power failures,  there are ways to tap solar energy when the grid goes down.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Sandy wiped out the power in areas like coastal Long Island and the Jersey Shore, what should have been beacons of hope — hundreds of solar panels glinting from residential rooftops — became symbols of frustration.

articles.headline: Retailers Add Politics and Nature to Their Holiday Worry List
articles.snippet: Some toy and game makers have held off product introductions, experienced logistics problems and reduced inventory because of recent events.
articles.abstract: Some toy and game makers have held off product introductions, experienced logistics problems and reduced inventory because of recent events.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many retailers have more than the usual riding on sales beginning this Thanksgiving weekend.

articles.headline: Early Dividend for Wal-Mart Is Latest Move in Tax Tactics
articles.snippet: Rescheduling dividend payments and selling stocks are among the strategies being employed to avoid higher tax rates set to take effect in 2013.
articles.abstract: Rescheduling dividend payments and selling stocks are among the strategies being employed to avoid higher tax rates set to take effect in 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: What a difference six days makes.

articles.headline: Tax Talks Raise Bar for Richest Americans
articles.snippet: The changes being discussed by the president and Congressional Republicans would take the biggest bite from the highest earners and a smaller share from those earning less than $500,000.
articles.abstract: The changes being discussed by the president and Congressional Republicans would take the biggest bite from the highest earners and a smaller share from those earning less than $500,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: By most measures, the personal finances of Anne Zimmerman, a small-business owner in Cincinnati, have little in common with those of Oracle’s chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison.

articles.headline: Private Equity and Hostess Stumbling Together
articles.snippet: While few tears should be shed for the private equity firm Ripplewood, the owner of Hostess brands, no one should conclude that Ripplewood was trying to make a quick profit and then leave.
articles.abstract: While few tears should be shed for the private equity firm Ripplewood, the owner of Hostess brands, no one should conclude that Ripplewood was trying to make a quick profit and then leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: “What’s happening with Hostess Brands is a microcosm of what’s wrong with America, as Bain-style Wall Street vultures make themselves rich by making America poor.”

articles.headline: After Obama, Christie Wants a G.O.P. Hug
articles.snippet: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who praised the president just before Election Day, is trying to tame the fury of fellow Republicans who feel he betrayed Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who praised the president just before Election Day, is trying to tame the fury of fellow Republicans who feel he betrayed Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after Hurricane Sandy shattered the shores of New Jersey, Gov. Chris Christie picked up the phone to take on a different kind of recovery work: taming the Republican Party fury over his effusive embrace of President Obama.

articles.headline: For Tax Pledge and Its Author, a Test of Time
articles.snippet: Some Congressional Republicans say they resent being hamstrung by a pledge created by the lobbyist Grover Norquist that they signed years ago, and some have defected.
articles.abstract: Some Congressional Republicans say they resent being hamstrung by a pledge created by the lobbyist Grover Norquist that they signed years ago, and some have defected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Next to the oath of office, it has been perhaps the most important commitment that Republicans in Congress can make. It is called simply “the Pledge,” and its enforcer is such a fixture in the party that he is known simply by his first name, Grover.

articles.headline: Easing of Restraints in Cuba Renews Debate on U.S. Embargo
articles.snippet: A new argument is gaining currency, even among many Cubans who had stayed on the sidelines: that more assistance from Americans could speed up tentative moves toward capitalism.
articles.abstract: A new argument is gaining currency, even among many Cubans who had stayed on the sidelines: that more assistance from Americans could speed up tentative moves toward capitalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — “If I could just get a lift,” said Francisco López, imagining the addition of a hydraulic elevator as he stood by a rusted Russian sedan in his mechanic’s workshop here. All he needed was an investment from his brother in Miami or from a Cuban friend there who already sneaks in brake pads and other parts for him.

articles.headline:
U.S. Seeks
Truce on Gaza
as Enemies
Step Up Attacks
articles.snippet: Efforts to agree on a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas intensified, with help from Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, but the sides struggled to achieve even a brief pause in fighting.
articles.abstract: Efforts to agree on a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas intensified, with help from Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, but the sides struggled to achieve even a brief pause in fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Efforts to agree on a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas intensified Tuesday, but the struggle to achieve even a brief pause in the fighting emphasized the obstacles to finding any lasting solution.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Ex-Trader Sentenced In Loss at UBS
articles.snippet: Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader, was given a seven-year jail sentence after he was found guilty on two charges of fraud for actions that prompted a multibillion-dollar trading loss at the Swiss bank, though he was found not guilty on four co...
articles.abstract: Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader, was given a seven-year jail sentence after he was found guilty on two charges of fraud for actions that prompted a multibillion-dollar trading loss at the Swiss bank, though he was found not guilty on four counts of false accounting.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Hewlett’s Loss: A Folly Unfolds, by the Numbers
articles.snippet: Hewlett can’t escape an onslaught of bad news. In recent years, what was once a giant of Silicon Valley has been buffeted by management turnover, board controversy and waning profits.
articles.abstract: Hewlett can’t escape an onslaught of bad news. In recent years, what was once a giant of Silicon Valley has been buffeted by management turnover, board controversy and waning profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Hewlett-Packard, the alarm bells started ringing less than a year after the technology company bought a British software maker for $11.1 billion.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Michael J. de la Merced
